HOME.line_1: Pierre Auguste Renoir was an important French plastic artist of the 19th century. He was part of Impressionism and stood out for his beautiful paintings.
HOME.line_2: He was born on February 25, 1841, in the French city of Limoges.
HOME.line_3: As a child, he showed great interest in the visual arts. As a child he worked as a decorator in a porcelain factory in Paris. At the age of 18, Renoir began painting and decorating blinds and fans.
HOME.line_4: In 1862, he went to study at the Academy of Fine Arts. He also studied at the academy of Swiss painter Charles Gabriel Gleyre. In this academy he met other famous artists of the time, such as Claude Monet and Alfred Sisley. From Monet, Renoir received influence in the treatment of light, and the work with colors was influenced by Delacroix.
HOME.line_5: His first artistic exhibition took place in Paris, in 1864. However, he did not get much recognition. Recognition came only in 1874, during the first exhibition of artists of the new Impressionist school.
HOME.line_6: In 1870, Renoir enlisted in the French army in the Franco-Prussian War. However, a year later, he left the conflict due to health problems.
HOME.line_7: In 1874, his painting Le Moulin de la Galette was recognized as a great Impressionist work of art.
HOME.line_8: Renoir's artistic career was consolidated with a solo exhibition held in Paris, at the Durand-Ruel gallery, in 1883.
HOME.line_9: The last 20 years of his life, Renoir suffered from his health. Having a joint disease (arthritis), the artist continued painting with difficulty. He tied the brush to his arm in order to carry out his works. Even so, he created rich and important works.
HOME.line_10: He died on December 3, 1919, aged 78, in Cagnes-sur-Mer (city in southwest France).
